news.title: ICE Started Ramping Up Its Surveillance Arsenal Immediately After Donald Trump Won
news.description: US Immigration and Customs Enforcement put out a fresh call for contracts for surveillance technologies before an anticipated surge in the number of people it monitors ahead of deportation hearings.
news.api_content: Compared to its recent November notice, ICE was more detailed about its 2025 plans in a different notice released last year. This earlier notice shows that ICE was preparing for a more intense immigr… [+2023 chars]
news.summary:
The notice signals the mechanisms through which ICE will expand its intensive surveillance of people awaiting deportation hearings—a list that could grow from under 200,000 to more than 5 million.
However, it’s likely that many granular aspects of a mass monitoring, detention, and deportation program would be planned by private companies contracting with ICE.
The notice says companies must have facilities with “suitably large intake rooms” for people being enrolled in ICE surveillance.
For ICE, according to the November notice, the program offers “considerable cost savings” compared to detention.
So even if Trump follows through on his promise of mass detention, it’s likely that ISAP would be a significant aspect of any mass deportation program.
news.text_preview:
On November 6, just hours after news outlets declared that Donald Trump had been elected the next president of the United States, Immigration and Customs Enforcement posted a notice asking companies to submit plans for how they would expand ICE’s system of ankle monitors, GPS trackers, biometric check-in technology, and human agents monitoring “non-citizens” awaiting immigration court hearings or deportation.

The notice signals the mechanisms through which ICE will expand its intensive surveillance of people awaiting deportation hearings—a list that could grow from under 200,000 to more than 5 million.

Throughout Trump’s presidential campaign, he has promised to execute “the largest deportation operation in American history.” Beyond promising workplace raids and giant detention “camps,” Trump hasn’t released specific plans for how his mass deportations would work. However, it’s likely that many granular aspects of a mass monitoring, detention, and deportation program would be planned...
news.short_summary:
The notice signals the mechanisms through which ICE will expand its intensive surveillance of people awaiting deportation hearings—a list that could grow from under 200,000 to more than 5 million.
However, it’s likely that many granular aspects of a mass monitoring, detention, and deportation program would be planned by private companies contracting with ICE.
The notice says companies must have facilities with “suitably large intake rooms” for people being enrolled in ICE surveillance.
For ICE, according to the November notice, the program offers “considerable cost savings” compared to detention.
So even if Trump follows through on his promise of mass detention, it’s likely that ISAP would be a significant aspect of any mass deportation program..

news.title: We Break Down the Internet’s Future Under Trump 2.0
news.description: WIRED global editorial director Katie Drummond joins this week to discuss what the fragmented internet did for the Trump campaign, and what the incoming Trump administration means for the internet.
news.api_content:
Leah Feiger: Enough trillions that don't actually currently exist in that budget.
Katie Drummond: Exactly. So thinking about that very messy, very human business and Elon Musk and Donald Trump in a … [+5020 chars]
news.summary:
If the goal was to get Trump elected and get himself into a seat of power, then who cares about that money that he lost?
I mean, it's essentially deficit funding what has become and is increasingly a right wing, conservative echo chamber that serves as a megaphone for the Trump administration and his acolytes, then job well done.
And even if it's not because of an incoming Trump administration, it's just good practice.
And I think for people and for institutions, I think it's also an interesting moment to think about what your lines are.
Really thinking about, OK, we need to spend some time with our lawyers and talk about the worst-case scenario.
news.text_preview:
Leah Feiger: Enough trillions that don't actually currently exist in that budget.

Katie Drummond: Exactly. So thinking about that very messy, very human business and Elon Musk and Donald Trump in a room making decisions about it, where you're really not seeing a lot of empathy, you're not seeing a lot of nuanced thinking about people and what people need. That is very stressful.

Leah Feiger: Absolutely. And on the X point, a slight devil's advocate there is that it depends on what the goal was. If the goal was to actually keep X as this profitable business communications for the world, et cetera, then yeah, absolutely, he failed. If the goal was to get Trump elected and get himself into a seat of power, then who cares about that money that he lost?

Katie Drummond: Great point.

Leah Feiger: He won that back tenfold over the last week with Tesla's stock and probably some upcoming government contracts and lack of regulations. Which I guess is into the, are you subsidizing your communi...
news.short_summary:
If the goal was to get Trump elected and get himself into a seat of power, then who cares about that money that he lost?
I mean, it's essentially deficit funding what has become and is increasingly a right wing, conservative echo chamber that serves as a megaphone for the Trump administration and his acolytes, then job well done.
And even if it's not because of an incoming Trump administration, it's just good practice.
And I think for people and for institutions, I think it's also an interesting moment to think about what your lines are.
Really thinking about, OK, we need to spend some time with our lawyers and talk about the worst-case scenario..

news.title: After the Election, California (Yes, That Hellscape) Will Keep Moving the World Forward No Matter What
news.description: The state has been written off as a woke wasteland. But it's still inventing the future on a bunch of frontiers nobody's talking about. Even if Trump wins, it will remain a golden, global example.
news.api_content: Just take the area of gasoline-powered transportation. After World War II, when American car culture was famously getting minted in Southern California, the state used a gas tax hike to build out one… [+5644 chars]
news.summary:
If she wins, what she knows from California will presumably affect her approach to the country and the world.
But if she doesn’t get that far, California is likely to chug along with all the more purpose, maintaining its nation-scale example of how else things can be done.
When done, this will be among the very fastest mainline high-speed rail systems running anywhere on Earth—at 220 mph.
But I’ve been following the back-and-forth for more than a decade, and I’ve started to see California’s high-speed rail project with a new clarity.
That’s where California is with high-speed rail.
news.text_preview:
It would be one thing if this were just a history lesson. But the same kind of dynamic is playing out right now in a few crucial arenas that virtually no one beyond California is talking about. And I’m happy to report that the America taking shape on its Pacific coast is again inventing solutions far more rapidly than conventional wisdom has accounted for.

I was bullish on these emerging transformations even before Kamala Harris became the Democratic nominee for president. If she wins, what she knows from California will presumably affect her approach to the country and the world. Her California-ness is one of the least-discussed but most important aspects of her, including the upbeat approach to today’s diversity and tomorrow’s opportunities that is such a contrast to Donald Trump.

But if she doesn’t get that far, California is likely to chug along with all the more purpose, maintaining its nation-scale example of how else things can be done. Whoever guides national politics, Califo...
news.short_summary:
If she wins, what she knows from California will presumably affect her approach to the country and the world.
But if she doesn’t get that far, California is likely to chug along with all the more purpose, maintaining its nation-scale example of how else things can be done.
When done, this will be among the very fastest mainline high-speed rail systems running anywhere on Earth—at 220 mph.
But I’ve been following the back-and-forth for more than a decade, and I’ve started to see California’s high-speed rail project with a new clarity.
That’s where California is with high-speed rail..

news.title: 20 Best Early Black Friday Deals of 2024 to Shop Right Now
news.description: It doesn’t officially arrive until November 29, but the Black Friday deals have already begun. Shop steep discounts on gear tested and approved by our editors.
news.api_content: Black Friday is well-known as the day when retailers slash prices to kick off the holiday shopping season and clear out stock ahead of the new year. The rise of online shopping expanded the season to… [+10606 chars]
news.summary:
The WIRED team boasts decades of experience in product testing and a nose for sniffing out the best deals using a suite of price-tracking tools.
For Black Friday, we cross-reference our buying guide recommendations with the latest sale prices to find the best early Black Friday deals on gadgets and gizmos worth owning.
The latest Apple Watch Series 10 (8/10, WIRED Recommends) is the best Apple Watch you can buy.
Photograph: Ryan WaniataSamsung's second-tier OLED (9/10, WIRED Recommends) is one of WIRED reviewer Ryan Waniata’s favorite TVs of the year.
The tri-band Eero Pro 6E (7/10, WIRED Recommends) mesh adds the 6-GHz band to the familiar 2.4-GHz and 5-GHz bands.
news.text_preview:
Black Friday is the big day for retailers slashing prices to kick off the holiday shopping season and clear out their 2024 stock. But you don’t have to wait to carve the Thanksgiving turkey and watch the Cowboys lose to snag discounts, because the best early Black Friday deals are live already.

The WIRED team boasts decades of experience in product testing and a nose for sniffing out the best deals using a suite of price-tracking tools. For Black Friday, we cross-reference our buying guide recommendations with the latest sale prices to find the best early Black Friday deals on gadgets and gizmos worth owning. Someone from the WIRED Reviews team has tested every product we include in our deals coverage, so you can rest easy knowing we don't highlight low prices on low-quality goods.

We strive to find deals at their best price ever, or very close to it (some match previous discounts, but we have never seen them lower unless stated).

Updated November 19, 2024: We added deals on devices...
news.short_summary:
The WIRED team boasts decades of experience in product testing and a nose for sniffing out the best deals using a suite of price-tracking tools.
For Black Friday, we cross-reference our buying guide recommendations with the latest sale prices to find the best early Black Friday deals on gadgets and gizmos worth owning.
The latest Apple Watch Series 10 (8/10, WIRED Recommends) is the best Apple Watch you can buy.
Photograph: Ryan WaniataSamsung's second-tier OLED (9/10, WIRED Recommends) is one of WIRED reviewer Ryan Waniata’s favorite TVs of the year.
The tri-band Eero Pro 6E (7/10, WIRED Recommends) mesh adds the 6-GHz band to the familiar 2.4-GHz and 5-GHz bands..

news.title: Lomography’s new instant camera uses a glass lens for sharper photos
news.description: Lomography’s new Lomo’Instant Wide Glass camera features an upgraded 90mm glass lens for potentially sharper results while using Fujifilm Instax Wide stock.
news.api_content:
Lomographys new instant camera uses a glass lens for sharper photos
Lomographys new instant camera uses a glass lens for sharper photos
 / The new LomoInstant Wide Glass features a 90mm multi-coate… [+2709 chars]
news.summary:
Lomography has announced an upgraded version of its Lomo’Instant Wide Camera that swaps the original’s 90mm plastic lens for one made with multi-coated glass.
The Lomo’Instant Wide Glass is available now for $279, where as the all-plastic Lomo’Instant Wide Camera Black Edition is still $169.
The Lomo’Instant Wide Glass includes a lens cap that doubles as a wireless shutter remote.
A sample photo taken with the Lomo’Instant Wide Glass camera.
Image: LomographyThe Lomo’Instant Wide Glass’ lens offers four focus zones including an infinity position for landscape photography and a close-up option that can focus on subjects just 0.98-feet away.
news.text_preview:
Lomography has announced an upgraded version of its Lomo’Instant Wide Camera that swaps the original’s 90mm plastic lens for one made with multi-coated glass. The company says its new Lomo’Instant Wide Glass is the “sharpest instant camera on earth,” but while it probably outperforms other Lomography offerings, it’s up against instant alternatives like the Nons SL660 which is compatible with EF mount lenses. And in either case, it’s still going to be held back by the limitations of instant film.

Those upgraded optics come with a much steeper price tag. The Lomo’Instant Wide Glass is available now for $279, where as the all-plastic Lomo’Instant Wide Camera Black Edition is still $169. Fujifilm’s own Instax Wide 400 is even cheaper at $149.95, while Fujifilm’s Instax Wide film stock, which is what this new camera uses, is $18.99 for 20 exposures.

The Lomo’Instant Wide Glass includes a lens cap that doubles as a wireless shutter remote. Image: Lomography

Due to the wide film stock it u...
news.short_summary:
